1.25 years of my experience, broken down into 6 mins forÂ you.

Itâ€™s crazy how amateur I was when I started writing.

But itâ€™s even crazier knowing how the same fingers who wrote this embarrassing piece are the same fingers that got me to the top Medium stories, Fast Company, HuffingtonPost, Lifehack, Thought Catalog, Social Media Examinerâ€¦.and a bunch more I canâ€™t remember.

You might be wondering,

Did I take online courses? Did I know the editors of these giant publications? Did I enjoy writing?

Nope, nope and definitely not.

Writing was never my skill, or something I felt passionate about. I sucked at it. BIG time.

My thoughts would scatter in all directions like pool balls. Iâ€™d make awkward word choices (some of which I made up, or thought existed in the dictionary). And the worst oneâ€Šâ€”â€Šforgetting what I really wanted to say in my message.

Sadly, my mind goes on auto-pilot once I hit the details. ğŸ˜‘

What Iâ€™m trying to say here is: Iâ€™m nobody special when it comes to writing.

I had to keep climbing the mountain, just like everyone else, until finally, I wrote the most heartfelt piece in my entire life, which soon got filled with dozens of repliesâ€Šâ€”â€Šmost wishing me the best for my future. This, alone, motivated me to keep going. To keep writing. Every single day. Rain or shine.

Now I get about 50,000+ views for 4â€“5 posts that I publish every month.

And a read ratio that averages around 40%.

TLDR: If you want to be a better writer, you need to put in the work. Thereâ€™s no shortcut aroundÂ it.

Luckily, Iâ€™ve been through most of the work. So hereâ€™re 25 insights Iâ€™ve learned from writing that I believe will help you with yours.

  1. Just write. 80% of success is just showing upâ€Šâ€”â€Šon Facebook, Twitter, Medium, Quora, GetPocket, whichever platform you use most. The key is to get your name stuck to peopleâ€™s minds to the point where they canâ€™t help but think of you offline.
  2. Never, ever, waste your readerâ€™s time. Youâ€™d only be wasting yours.
  3. Write down EVERY idea that comes to you. Doesnâ€™t matter if youâ€™re half-asleep, talking to a friend, or driving. It takes 8 seconds before you get distracted and forget about it. So make sure you keep a notebook and pen by your side, or a note-taking app (if you prefer).
  4. Get hurt. Fall in love. Vent out your anger. Iâ€™m not saying this should be your mission, but know that every little emotion fuels your writing. You wonâ€™t notice this at first, but once your readers start dropping a bombful of comments in your post, you will.
  5. Build an email list. People are very forgetful when it comes to bookmarking their favorite writers. So remind them of why they subscribed to you by sending them daily/weekly updates. Youâ€™ll start seeing your responses and recommends skyrocket like never before.
  6. Learn the rules of grammar, then learn to break them. If you ever want your writing to stand out, you need to â€œthink outside the book.â€ Do things other writers are scared to try.
  7. Improve your read ratio, not your views. Views are important (donâ€™t get me wrong), but having a high read ratio grows your name in the long run. Sure, itâ€™s a bigger challenge getting people to read an entire post, especially when we have so many online and offline distractions to deal with. But the more people who find your stories fascinating, the more followers and subscribers (See point #5) youâ€™ll get. And before you know it, your readers will dig deep into your social networks, trying to figure out who you are and what you do.
    Â Isnâ€™t that more worth your time than blasting mediocre stuff to those who just come-and-go-and-possibly-never-come-back?
    Â (See point #2)
    Â Point taken.
  8. Disconnect from the Internet and the rest of the world. You get more work done if you just focus and write.
  9. Write what you know. Write what interests you. Write about your lifeâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s the one thing people canâ€™t steal from you.
  10. Keep a dictionary and thesaurus available whenever you write. Thereâ€™re dozens of ways to say one thing better.
  11. Be as descriptive as you can.
    Â Instead of: By the time I hit 24, I was extremely underweight.
    Â Try: By the time I hit 24, I was 5'5" and bearing a 112 lb figure. You want more meat on your hook.
  12. Read what successful writers write. Thereâ€™s a reason why thousands of people follow them.
  13. Read what successful writers recommend. Most of them have read plenty enough to know whatâ€™s good and whatâ€™s s***.
  14. Donâ€™t stay put in one spot for too long. Your creativity will sulk (trust me, I know). Move. Get up. Take a 15 min walk. The faster your blood moves, the faster oxygen gets to your brain. Hence, better ideas, better results.
  15. Link back to your old posts. Because the more posts you publish, the further your old ones are pushed out of sight.
  16. Donâ€™t cheap out on your headline. If you canâ€™t attract people to click on your post, then you wasted your whole time writing a piece nobody wants to read. Itâ€™s the same as if you never wrote anything at all.Â 
    Â (My personal guide to writing a great headline)
  17. Shut your inner editor up and understand that 1st drafts are always horrible and ugly. Just finish what you started, then proofread once youâ€™re done. Itâ€™s easier to fix a bad story than to create a story right from scratch.
  18. Get Grammarly and save yourself from the harsh remarks of grammar Nazis. Itâ€™ll auto-highlight your grammar & spelling mistakes as soon you hit space or enter.
  19. Show more whitespace. Itâ€™s an eye-sore to read paragraphs vs sentences.
  20. Everyone says this, but read, read, read. Itâ€™s the fastest way to expand your vocabulary and mold your writing, using all sorts of styles from different writers.
  21. Dump out those passive verbs (e.g. is/be/are/has) for action verbs.
    Â Instead of: I was inspired by her work ethics.Â 
    Â     Say: Her work ethics inspired me.
  22. If youâ€™re new on Medium, write shorter. This lets readers get a feel for how & what you write. Plus, you can probably push out 2x more postsâ€Šâ€”â€Šanother way to grow your name in the beginning.
  23. Write as if youâ€™re talking to a friend. Write the way you talk. Itâ€™ll be extremely refreshing because the majority of writers still write in proper English.
  24. Write for 30 minutes everyday. This is the basic habit for mastering a skill.
  25. After you post, reach out to the editors of big name sites and submit your post. Itâ€™ll be one extra source of traffic to grow your name.
